section.title: Subtyping
section.para: A type S is a subtypesubtype of a type T, written S ≤≤ T, if a value of type S can be used in any context expecting a value of type T.
A type U is a supertypesupertype of a type T if T ≤≤ U.
Subtyping is reflexive: S ≤ S. Subtyping is also transitive: if S ≤ T and T ≤ U, then S ≤ U.
If an expression has type S and S ≤ T, then that expression also has type T. This is called subsumption.
Types in Orc form a bounded lattice. The lattice is ordered by the subtyping relation, its maximal element is the special type TopTop, and its minimal element is the special type Bot.

section.title: Top
section.para: Top is the universal type. Every value has type Top. Every type is a subtype of Top.

section.title: Bot
section.para: Bot is the empty type. No value has type Bot. Bot is a subtype of every type. An expression has type Bot only if it never publishes any values.

Bot has an interesting status in Orc. In other typed languages, if an expression has type Bot, this usually indicates a guaranteed error, infinite loop, or other failure to return a value. Since sequential programming rarely involves subexpressions that are guaranteed never to return, Bot is usually just a curiosity or a formal artifact of the type system, and indeed many type systems do not have a Bot type at all.

In Orc, however, Bot is very useful, since it is frequently the case that Orc expressions are written to carry out ongoing concurrent activities but never publish any values, and the type system can use the type Bot to indicate that no publications will ever be seen from such expressions.

section.title: Join
section.para: A common supertypecommon supertype of two types S and T is any type U such that S ≤ U and T ≤ U. The joinjoin of S and T is the least common supertype of S and T: it is a subtype of every common supertype of S and T.

Some common cases:
The join of T and T is T. If S ≤ T, then the join of S and T is T. The join of T and Top is Top. The join of T and Bot is T.
The join of two unrelated types is usually Top.

section.title: Meet
section.para: A common subtypecommon subtype of two types S and T is any type U such that U ≤ S and U ≤ T. The meetmeet of S and T is the greatest common subtype of S and T: it is a supertype of every common subtype of S and T.

Some common cases:
The meet of T and T is T. If S ≤ T, then the meet of S and T is S. The meet of T and Top is T. The meet of T and Bot is Bot.
The meet of two unrelated types is usually Bot.

section.title: Variance
section.para: When types contain other types as components, such as a tuple type or a polymorphic type, the subtype relationship between these composite types depends on the subtype relationships between their components. If a component of a type S is a subtype of the corresponding component in another type T, does that imply that S ≤ T? To answer this question, we need a concept called variancevariance.

Tuple types, record types, and list types are all covariant contexts. In a function type, the return type is a covariant context, but the argument types are contravariant contexts. The type parameters of mutable value types are invariant contexts.

The variance of the type parameters in an aliased type or datatype is determined from the definition itself, by observing the contexts in which the parameters appear. If a parameter appears only in covariant contexts, it is covariant. If it appears only in contravariant contexts, it is contravariant. If it appears in both contexts, it is invariant.
